subject: Ethics
title: Water Rights and Scarcity
description: A 1-minute de-risking session on Water Rights and Scarcity.

hook.text: NestlÃ© once pumped water from a drought-stricken California town and sold it back in bottles.

buildup.text: Over 2 billion people lack safe drinking water. Meanwhile, corporations bottle and sell water for profit.

discovery.text: In 2010, the UN declared access to clean water a basic human right. But rights don't fill empty wells.

twist.text: Water privatization promises efficiency but often raises prices, locking out the poorest communities.

climax.text: The ethics question: is water a commodity to be traded or a commons that belongs to everyone?

punchline.text: When water has a price tag, thirst becomes a class issue.

quiz.question: What ethical tension surrounds water privatization?
options: Privatization can raise prices and exclude the poorest from accessing a basic right
Private companies always provide cleaner water than governments
Water scarcity is a myth used to drive up prices
